fullText: Memory doesn’t serve me well in reviewing “Bob Fosse’s Dancin’,” which opened Sunday at the Music Box on Broadway. I saw the original show, simply titled “Dancin’,” and remember very little about it. Oddly enough, I do remember the date I saw the show, because it was the first preview (March 28, 1978), and some people at the Shubert Organization had decided to give the Broadhurst Theatre a little makeover.
rejectionReasoning: claude: This appears to be an incomplete excerpt that only contains personal anecdotes about seeing the original 1978 production, with no evaluation of the current Broadway revival.; openai: The text is primarily a personal anecdote about the critic's memory of the original production, not an evaluative review of the current Broadway show.; gemini: The text is mostly about the critic's memory of seeing the original production, not a review of the current revival. There's no evaluation of the current show's quality.; kimi: The text contains only biographical context about the critic's memory of the original 1978 production and mentions the current opening date, but provides no evaluation of the current Broadway production's quality, performances, or overall merit.
bwwExcerpt: I don’t recall how Fosse ended his 'Dancin’.' Cilento ends his with a real flourish. He gives each of his nearly two dozen dancers the full-star treatment, complete with his, her or their name emblazoned (lighting by David Grill) in tall letters on the upstage wall. Cilento, who appeared in the original company of 'A Chorus Line,' presents the anti-'Chorus Line' with this extended curtain call. These quick solo turns feature some of the evening’s best choreography. Here and elsewhere in the show

keyPhrases.quote: These quick solo turns feature some of the evening's best choreography.
